critique: This document pertains to land management and the modification of the Tongass National Forest boundary in Alaska. It involves transferring land out of the National Forest for homesteading by ex-service men and then the general public. It is difficult to assess a strong ideological tilt. The action could be seen as favoring private land ownership (conservative) or supporting veterans (moderate). Immigration is not addressed. Executive power is used to modify the forest boundary, but this seems within established legal frameworks. Federalism is implicated as it involves federal land management. National security is not a primary concern. Economic regulation is indirectly affected by opening land for private use. Social inclusion is somewhat addressed by prioritizing ex-service men, but this is a specific group. Therefore, the initial scores are as follows:
